Reviews.Title: Great for a Senior, less so for the Elderly
Reviews.Author: J. Norvell "peaknorvel"
Reviews.Content: The SnapFon ezONE-C Senior cell phone is about as simple as the standard model cell phones that you used to buy ten years ago.  It is NOT as simple as a landline phone and that made the phone perplexing to the 91 year old woman that I got this for.  It is smaller and lighter than I thought it would be, but that could be a plus or minus.  The buttons are about the same as a cheap calculator; they are large but you need to press in the center.  It has a radio function and a flashlight, which may delight a less elderly person, but I taped over the side switches that operate those with gaffers tape so that they wouldn't confuse.  The display is large and clear.The phone works with an AT&T; SIM card.  I bought a SIM card on Amazon, but, as it turns out, you must actually buy one from AT&T; anyway or they won't process you to get on their network.  The purchased SIM card did allow me to get the phone going earlier however, although it did take repeated phone calls to AT&T; and most of an afternoon to get the phone set up.  The phone comes with a SIM card from "PureTalk", a reseller of cell phone time, and I presume that setting up with them would be easier.The advantage of a cell phone is that any landline number can be transferred to it.  My phone user was being moved into an assisted living facility, just far enough away that she couldn't get a landline with the same number without keeping the old landline and buying a forwarding service -- sheesh.  The port to the cell phone went well, but, again, it did take some time on the line with AT&T; folks.  I just added her to our family plan and she is saving a lot of money, although you do need to absorb the cost of the phone, the SIM card, and a $40 fee for the new service.  She no longer needs the landline at her old home.My elderly user is perplexed that she needs to press down for a period of time to autodial, but she only presses for a short time to hang up.  As a result, she keeps turning the phone off, since the "hang up" button is also the power on and off button.  For seniors that are used to using cell phones previously, this may not be a problem.  For a life-long landline user, this is a problem.

Reviews.Title: easy to use phone
Reviews.Author: Melissa Z Schilke
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for a developmentaly disabled person.  Great, simple to use, phone.  When I brought it into T-Mobile to get a simcard for it, the staff passed it around commented on how easy it was to understand how to use. The numbers on this phone are really big.  The SOS button on the back is a great feature that can be programed to dial 911 and send Text to additional phone number.

Reviews.Title: Great Phone for Aging Parents!
Reviews.Author: nlh
Reviews.Content: After doing much research on phones for seniors and reading many reviews, I chose the Snapfon ezOne for my 77-year-old mother who is in the early stages of macular degeneration. She is not tech-savvy, but she's picked up quickly on the "how tos" for this phone. She loves the large, back-lit numbers and the ease of stopping and starting a call. She's amazed that she does not have to remember and "dial" phone numbers, since they are all saved in the phone. The recessed, red emergency button on the back of the phone gives me some peace of mind, for my mom is often out and about and lives very independently. She does not use the radio, as many other reviewers also mentioned. I also purchased the charging stand so she does not have to deal with issues related to bending to plug in the charging cord or inserting the tiny end into the phone; she merely puts the phone into the stand which remains connected to the electrical current via the cord that comes with the phone.

Reviews.Title: Lou A
Reviews.Author: Lou A
Reviews.Content: Snapfon has a host of benefits: moderate size, easy to hold square shape, easy read numbers,  simple answer and hang-up icons, no flipping case,  and especially the "Panic Button".  Other phones call one number with the panic button.  This one calls and texts 4 numbers in a scrolling sequence until there is an answer.  My mother has  a relative, a neighbor, the police, and the fire department. I can't tell you what a relief it is to know she has this phone.  Thanks.

Reviews.Title: simple phone for simple people
Reviews.Author: canonicalbrud "lover of truth and beauty"
Reviews.Content: Despite this phone's marketing to our beloved and often forgotten senior citizens, as a twenty-something I was interested in buying this phone for its advertised simple functionality (it's not a camera, an iPod, or a Gameboy; it's a phone). Most of the phones sold with pay-as-you-go plans are often the trashiest models with poor craftsmanship and half-working so-called "features", making it hard to find a good simple phone that just makes calls, sends and receives texts, has a recent call list and address book. The Snapfon is that hard-to-find gem of simplicity. Although it's not perfect, it's been my favorite of all the "non-smart" phones I've owned (which have included several Nokia and Motorola models, and even the Razr).Here are my favorite aspects:+Unlocked phone worked instantly with my T-mobile pay-as-you-go chip. No stupid unlock codes.+Battery life is long.+Screen lights up even in locked mode to illuminate the time.+LED flashlight works well.+Big buttons are nice to use.+Much lighter than your average brick phone.Here's what was keeping it from being a 5-star review:-Menu flow is too linear, making some actions seemingly dead ends. Cancel and delete both share the PWR/NO button, making some parts of the navigation dead-ends.-There's no way to do actions like browsing through the menus or turning on the phone silently while still having it in vibrate mode for calls or texts. Switching the phone to "silent mode" turns off all types of alerts and noises, including vibrate.-There's no free preview of text messages. Most other phones I've used let you preview the text message from the inbox which made it possible to read short messages without actually opening them. For using Google Voice text messaging, knowing who sent a text message is only possible by opening the message to see the header, which is a drag.-I can't figure out how to delete an unread text message. The option to delete only seems to be accessible after opening a text message, but which fortunately allows you to clear the entire inbox while deleting the one being read. Feature needs tweaking.-It's nice that the buttons are nice and big, but they seem to get pressed easily in the pocket. Hopefully the SOS button won't accidentally get pressed.-You have to directly enter a contact in the address book rather than typing in a number on the front screen and saving it, adding a name later.-While less features isn't necessarily bad, it's a little too expensive for how little it does.-FM radio really necessary? Whatever.Features wished for::? An alarm feature.:? USB connection to transfer contacts from computer address book (and maybe custom ring tones, but low priority).:? Bluetooth hands-free set compatibility.Bottom line: Pretty satisfied so far, despite phone's short-comings. More how simple phones should be.edit: Apparently my point about the chirps and noises while in vibrate mode or silent mode wasn't very clear, because got a personal call from ezONE telling me how to set the phone to vibrate. To be clear, the phone has a vibrate mode, but the buttons still chirp when you press them.

Reviews.Title: Senior Cell Phone - a great phone for anyone - especially the elderly
Reviews.Author: AC
Reviews.Content: My mom is 89 and is somewhat hard of hearing and a bit forgetful.  This exONE-C Senior Cell Phone is helping her to stay connected with her friends and family and is providing a level of security because it has some rather unique features as follows: 1. The ringer is adjustable but if set at high volume it is EXTREMELY LOUD and rings like a traditional bell type ringer. (Even if you want a phone which will ensure that no calls will be missed in a noisy environment, this is one to consider. 2. The volume of the call is easily adjustable without needing to go into any menus - there is an up/down rocker button on the side of the unit which can PRESET your incoming volume so your setting from the previous call will be retained for the next call.  The receiver can be set to be much louder than a conventional phone and the clarity is fine.  There is also a speakerphone which can be engaged with one button push.  3. The button size and simplicity of the layout is excellent.  4. The display is brightly lit in a yellow background with dark grey LCD numerals that are close to a 1/2 in. tall.  The display is simply one line but if the content that is to be displayed (such as a long name, etc.) has too many characters to fit in the display window, then the line scrolls repeatedly to show its entire content.  The display is designed to stay lit for a somewhat longer period of inactivity than is usually the case.  So if the person using the phone is a slow dialer or needs to check the number a few times while dialing, the backlight will not turn off that quickly.  When the phone is not in use, the display is still useful as it becomes a digital clock with large numbers and also indicates the day and date.  5. The size of the phone is slim and compact - certainly not a clunker.  It is basically just a little taller than the width of the hand that will be holding it and the width is about 2.5 in or so - a comfortable size to hold.  6. Once up to 9 one touch speed dial numbers are entered (complete with names), it is a simple 2 button press process to dial any of the 9 locations.  The 10th preset is set for 911.  Of course, the phone can be used to manually dial a phone number quite easily.  There is a unique red button (the size of a nickel on the back of the phone which can be programmed to dial several numbers sequentially in the case of an emergency - just press and hold the button for a moment and your selected recipients will receive a pre-recorded message asking for assistance. 7. There is a built-in digital FM radio with an on/off switch on the side of the phone for those times when you might want to listen to the news or music.  The radio uses the built-in speaker to provide a reasonable volume capability.  However,  I was only able to receive one or two stations well enough to enjoy.  Maybe if earphones are connected (there is a stereo headphone jack) the reception might be better - I did not try this. 8. This phone is compatible with either the AT&T; or T-Mobile network.  Service can be purchased without any contracts from either provider.  There is also information enclosed if you want to order service from Snapfon's own provider offering.  9. Battery life so far appears to be acceptable, with my mother needing to charge the phone every couple of days or so with between talking an hour or two each day. There is a large 5 segment battery gauge on one edge of the display while the opposed edge has a similar gauge to indicate signal strength.  The only thing about this phone which would be confusing to an elderly person (and for anyone else) is the menu system if you want to review or edit the phonebook or to check the caller ID history to see what calls were missed.  It is possible to accidentally start to call a stored number when you think you are just scrolling through the names.  All in all, this is a rather unique and very useful phone.  Anyone with a need for an easy to use, hear and see cellular phone will probably not be disappointed with this choice - especially for its reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Great phone - Great Price
Reviews.Author: CarlyA
Reviews.Content: I ordered this phone for my 81 year old grandmother.  She has neuropathy in her hands, and thus, had a difficult time with the buttons, flip functions, etc, of a traditional cell phone - even those that were manufactured for the "senior" population.  What a wonderful surprise!  The phone is sleek, easy to use, and has fabulous details for emergency preparedness.The S.O.S button is unlike any other phone I have seen on the market.  It's "one-touch" functionality allows the user to alert pre-determined family and friends in the event of an emergency; even allowing for 911 contact if no other numbers can be reached.The snapfon's design is one that allows the customer to easlily hold  the phones and push the buttons even if only one hand is available.  Speakerphone option is clear and has the perfect sensitivity.We are so pleased with our Snapfon purchase.  They have truly reached a unique market segment with this phone that has been previously ignored or brushed over with little attention to the details.  Way to go, Snapfon for making us feel that our grandmother is safe and secure with this unique piece of technoloy!

Reviews.Title: SIMPLE IS BETTER
Reviews.Author: George - Liverpool, NY
Reviews.Content: Just received the Snapfon yesterday. I am in my fifties and ordered it because I believe in the philosophy of "KISS", Keep It Stupidly Simple and, of course, easy to use. Please find below initial likes and dislikes.LIKES  1) Very large, well lighted, and real easy to push numbers great when driving, in dark, etc., or just being human.  2) Two of the multiple ring tones are real cool: Hawaii Five-O and opening title song to James Bond movies.  3) Has a speaker phone engaged by holding the "0" key or pushing the green "OK" key and then selecting speaker.  4) You can elect to have woman's voice announce the number keys each time you push one when dialing.  5) Built-in LED flash light with switch on side of phone.  6) Simple, amber back lighted screen which shows numbers and words with no pictures.  7) Center "MENU" button easy to push lets you maneuver menus with up and down push of button.  8) Three large key (green OK, yellow MENU, red PWR/NO) buttons for send call, access to menus, phone on/off, etc.  9) Ability to lock keys with a side mounted sliding lock/unlock switch.  10) Red SOS (Panic) button on back for calling up to four programmable, owner pre-set phone numbers.  11) It irritated my wife when I told her I was going to buy a "Senior Phone".  12) Loved the fact she had to eat her words when she actually liked it after it arrived. Told you so dear!DISLIKES  1) NO BLUETOOTH! Spoke to manufacturer about this before buying and expressed my concern. Some of us do drive.  2) Speaker is loud but not of the greatest quality at higher volumes.  3) Had to listen to my wife's mockery of me buying a "Senior Phone".

Reviews.Title: Snapfon
Reviews.Author: Rick
Reviews.Content: Its a great phone for a non techie senior citizen.  Bought one for my  80 year old mother who has become visually impaired, and she loves it.  I just bought a second one for my 92 year old aunt.  The programable button is especially valuable in the event of an emergency.  Great phone.

Reviews.Title: Great phone. More than gets the job done.
Reviews.Author: John M. Keeling "jmk"
Reviews.Content: I bought my father this phone to replace the Jitterbug which was too costly.This phone is awesome. Big keys. Loud ring tones. Feels good in the hand. Battery lasts forever.If you're wanting a safety phone for your oldster or a good phone for a youngster, this is the phone for you.

Reviews.Title: Snapfon
Reviews.Author: stacey IE
Reviews.Content: The phone had very poor contrast on the screen that shows the number being dialed. It would not be good for someone who needs good contrast and the backlight produced to much glare, instead of good lighting.

Reviews.Title: Snapfon
Reviews.Author: nikita
Reviews.Content: This phone was purchased for my mother, who is legally blind. Its very simple to use and I would recommend it very much. The large numbers are a plus, especially for anyone with a poor eye sight to use.

Reviews.Title: Great for Low Vision
Reviews.Author: CB
Reviews.Content: Bought this phone for my 87 year old Dad whom legally blind.  The buttons are easy to use but the best part is they speak to him!  Just popped in the sim card from his old phone and it was ready to go.

Reviews.Title: I Loved This Phone So Much I Wrote This On My Blog
Reviews.Author: David C LeSueur
Reviews.Content: All of the sales staff in the Apple Store looked like little kids. We were working with one who looked 14 – 14½ tops. “So you’d like to buy a new iPhone 5?” “Yes, we’d like one for my wife, but I just want something simple. My fingers and hands don’t work very well anymore. I need big buttons, not a touchscreen.”He stroked the peach fuzz on his chin, deep in thought. “I’ve never heard of a phone with big buttons.”There was a picture on the wall behind him of a woman with the caption “Hi, I’m Klare, the Store Manager. Let me know if I can help you!” She looked confident, knowledgeable, experienced. She looked at least 22. “Can I talk to your manager? Maybe she’ll have an idea.”Thirty seconds later, Klare was there, ready to help. “I just need a cell phone,” I said. “I don’t care about a touchscreen or the internet or texting or talking to Siri or any of those extra things. And it has to have big buttons.”“I’ve never seen a phone like that, but I’ve read about them on Wikipedia.” It was reassuring that Klare had done so much research at such an authoritative source. I could see why she was the Store Manager. “You might be able to find one on Ebay. The only problem is that often the seller doesn’t have the cords anymore.”My wife and I looked at each other and smiled. Our kids make fun of us because we have two boxes in the basement containing every electrical cord we have ever owned. It would be sweet revenge if we actually got to use one of them!Once home, I got on the internet and started to go to Ebay when I had a better idea. I googled “Cell Phones Big Buttons”. Exactly .29 seconds later I had about 1,830,000 results and bought the first phone on the list.I’ve had the phone about a week now and really like it, but clearly, its target audience is much older than I. For example, the phone gets FM radio reception. Only people over the age of 80 would think that was cool. (Mabel: “George, the cell phone comes with FM radio!” George: “Mabel, what in tarnation is FM?”) The ring tones that come with the phone are a phone ring from the 1920s, the Andy Griffith theme song and “Chattanooga Choo Choo”. The cool great-grandpas can also choose “Dragnet”, “Hawaii Five-0” and “James Bond”. It also has a special “funeral mode” which automatically changes the ring tone to “Amazing Grace”. The ring tone volume is adjustable, but even the softest level is louder than an infomercial in the middle of the night.There is also a keen safety feature which only people of a certain age can appreciate. If you can’t wait  for help to arrive if you dialed 911, there is a big red button on the back of the phone you can use to call for more immediate help. When you push the button, a VERY loud voice yells for help. The three standard yells you can choose from are “Help! I’ve fallen and I can’t get up!”, “Help! I have no idea what I’m doing here!” and ”Help! Someone stole my clothes!” You can also record a custom message. Mine says “Help! I can’t find my TV remote!”You may think my message is silly, but you would be wrong. Just the other day, I called Comcast to get some help with a technical issue we were having. The woman on the phone fixed my problem, then asked helpfully “Is there anything else I can do for you?”“Well, do you know where my TV remote is?”“The one upstairs or the one in the basement?”“The one upstairs.”“Did you look under the red pillow on the sofa?”Sure enough it was there! So you just never know.David LeSueur lives in Littleton, Colorado with his wife Mary. He was diagnosed with MS in 2000. He still has his TV remote, but is missing a brown sock. Could someone from Comcast please call him?

Reviews.Title: Exactly as Billed
Reviews.Author: @wealthcop
Reviews.Content: I purchased this phone for my 87 year-old mother.The phone comes factory unlocked for GSM chips.  It worked off the bat.  The keyboard lock, flashlight, volume and FM radio switches on the left and right sides of the phone are easy to use and worked well.  Comes with wall charger.The phone does exactly what it says and was easy to "program" in the information we wanted.  In fact, it imported all the numbers that had been on the SIM chip.I think my mother prefers this phone to all other phones she has used.  Many older people have arthritis.  They find opening up flip phones to be very difficult and can't do it in a timely manner.  She was so happy with this phone.My only complaint is that the housing appears to be cheap plastic, and not very thick at that.  I know I can't expect much from a $60 device, but I am worried that if the phone is dropped, the case might shatter.

Reviews.Title: Bought one - then bought two more - and will buy one for me too!
Reviews.Author: Tarysa
Reviews.Content: Love this phone - works great for my elderly parents.  My Dad has big hands and couldn't use my Mom's cell phone.  I bought this to replace Mom's phone and showed it to Dad - the buttons were big enough for him to use it - so bought him his own phone as well.  Only issue I had was that getting the back off and on took patience and determination when we first got the phones.  But I love the feature where the phone talks as you dial so you know you are dialing correctly.  I bought a third phone to replace my sister's cell as well.  These were great gift ideas - and now the entire family is all using the same brand and model of phone, so if anyone has problems with how to do something, I can answer them - or check it out myself without having to go to their house to get their phone.I fully intend to replace my own phone with this same model phone after Christmas.  We are not using the phone service that comes with the phones though - we all have AT&T; Go Phone accounts and this unlocked phone works perfectly with our existing AT&T; service.  All I had to do was charge the phones, and put our simm cards in the new phones and they worked.  No trips to the AT&T; Store - it was simple and easy.  Thank you for making something that men can use and elderly can use - without all the bells and whistles of the "smart phones", but with enough services that it meets the needs as an simple cell phone when you are on the go.

Reviews.Title: Large buttons are good, it's not simple to use however
Reviews.Author: dood_up_north
Reviews.Content: I purchased one of these and the buttons stopped responding. Amazon promptly refunded me and the second one seems fine. These things happen so this does not affect my review.I also purchased the cheap case ($5) and the cradle. Worthwhile additions.Let me start with the positives.  Large buttons. I got this for my step dad and this was the primary reason for the purchase. There is nothing else like it. Sound. The old skool ringer is VERY loud. The speakerphone is fairly loud. The earpiece is unfortunately just so-so volume wise. The mono screen is easy to see and that really helps battery life. You can also have the phone "speak" each button you press which can be useful. It's a quad band unlocked GSM phone (no GPRS or data) and you are not stuck with pricey service like Jitterbug. I'm using h2o, an AT&T; MVNO that costs $10 every 90 days (14c a minute airtime). There are lots and lots of options for service depending on user needs. These are the primary reasons for getting the phone and they make it worthwhile.There are two features of the phone that have no business being on this phone. 1. Flashlight. 2. Radio. Those two buttons on the side of the phone could confuse people and get left on by accident. I would have had the volume rockers on the left and the lock on the right.  That's it.The SOS button on the back is a good idea but confusing. It took a lot of reading to understand how it works. You program up to four numbers and it sends a SMS and dials each number in order until someone answers. You cannot turn off the SMS.You cannot turn off the annoying start up and shut down tones unless you silence everything (not recommended).The software running the menus is not simple.  It would have been nice to disable most of the functionality and remove it from the main menus. That would have made it much easier for a senior to use.The menus are somewhat confusing. I could write a book about it but 90% of the stuff in the menus should be hidden or eliminated.Still, overall, there are not a lot of senior phones out there, and this still rates at the top.

Reviews.Title: Great phone despite minor flaw
Reviews.Author: Eric H.
Reviews.Content: Great phone, both my parents love it.Pro:Big numbers on keypad and screen.Loud. They can hear the speaker phone at a noisy bus stop.Con:The flashlight and radio accidentally switches on in your pocket, even if you activate the keypad lock, quickly draining the battery. Either remove these two features, or redesign the keypad lock to disable them, too.Despite this small flaw, will recommend phone to my elderly relatives.

Reviews.Title: Best there is, but I'd pay more for better. Works in Canada with Rogers.
Reviews.Author: John Faughnan "John G Faughnan"
Reviews.Content: I bought my 83 yo mother the unlocked GSM Snapfon ezONE-C Senior Cell Phone with Big Buttons for about $80 (it's $60 now) along with its car charger (forgetting she doesn't drive any more!). I then carried it to her home in Montreal and activated on a Roger's 40 cent/min (but 0$/day) PayGo plan.My mother likes her Mac Mini and iPad, but she's largely blind, quite arthritic, and has peripheral neuropathy reducing her sense of touch. So most phones won't work for her. This was the only phone we could find that she might be able to use. She needs, for example, to be able to call for help when Montreal's sometimes unreliable wheelchair transport service fails to show up - leaving her stuck in her wheelchair as snow swirls, water freezes, and hungry wolves approach over the ice.It is impressive how few devices are made for people like my mother.  I assume the demand isn't there. Certainly if she were younger she might do well with a VoiceOver iPhone, but the combination of age and diminished touch make VoiceOver hard for her. In any case that was my best guess, but the next best choice to this $60 phone is probably a $700 iPhone 5.Based on limited use, here are my impressions of the device. I'll start with the bad, then the good. Bottom line: I think it will work, but I'd rather buy a better version for $100 than the current phone for $60.THE BAD- It doesn't get its time settings off the mobile network. Very weird.- I fear it doesn't  persistently store its configuration. I don't want to test this, but I think prolonged removal of the battery will wipe all setup - and setup is a bit painful. File this under "suspicion" not proven. Settings do survive a quick battery swap. (Maybe it's storing some data on the SIM card, in which case I might have been confused by a SIM swap.)- This is a very Chinese product -- feels like it was built for the Chinese or Japanese market. That is, it has a number of weird add-on features like an FM radio and a flashlight that mostly add complexity and seem weird for the US market. On the other hand, I think my mother might actually use the FM radio. It uses the ear set as an antenna. In my testing it worked well with an iPhone ear set and with iPod ear buds despite the manual saying only Nokia and SNAPFON earphones work.)- It has too many features that can simply cause confusion and will never be used, like 'conference call' and 'call waiting'. Even SMS is of dubious value. The radio introduces many options.- The power connector is small and hard for my mother to find. I stuck a rubber matt near it so she could find it. It is easily confused with the headphone jack.- It feels fragile and unreliable. We're not talking iPhone 5 build. I'd happily pay $40 more for better build quality.- Display is small and text layout is a bit off. I suspect it was designed to show characters, not Roman letters.- Buttons take some push -- they are cheap!- It comes with "PureTalk"; it's probably not the best PayGo solution but it's not entirely bad. For the US market I'd suggest H2O Wireless instead.THE GOOD-Big buttons!-Ringer is LOUD, and phone is loud and audible even at an intermediate setting.-The instruction manual is large type.-I could get a camera lanyard into the lanyard hoop with a bit of fiddling (essential accessory, should be bundled with phone).- It speaks numbers as they are entered. Great feature!- Seems to have very long battery life.- The quick dial numbers will work well I think, even though we decided not to enable the SOS feature for now.- Yes, the flashlight and radio are quirky, but my mother might actually come to like them.I created a large print 1 page handout for my mother that included a simplified version of usage directions and the numbers I programmed in for her.

Reviews.Title: No signal many times and incoming voice volume is too low for seniors and it cannot be adjusted
Reviews.Author: Tom Perkins
Reviews.Content: There is no signal often.  I bought this item for my father who has hearing Problem,but the incoming call volume is so low and he could not hear the conversation at all.  There is no way to adjust the incoming voice column. Will return it.

Reviews.Title: WARNING - ONLY 2G phone
Reviews.Author: AJ
Reviews.Content: No where does it say in the description that ATT is ONLY selling 3G sim cards, so this phone will NOT work on new accounts.If you have an old 2G sim card to throw in, then you are good, but otherwise, it will not work with the new 3G sim cards at ATT.

Reviews.Title: The Snapon cell phone
Reviews.Author: M. Messer
Reviews.Content: This cell phone was bought and set up for me by my niece.  I am legally blind but I can see the keyboard especially since it lights up when the phone is on.  It's small and easily carried in a pocket.  I like it very much. The sound is excellent so hearing is no problem.For a senior, I think it's the caterpillar's boots.

Reviews.Title: Easy cell phone
Reviews.Author: J. Johnston
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my 87 year old mother who has been using a cell phone for the last few years.  It can get much louder and is much easier than her previous phone.  The numbers are large,perfect for her.  When she forgets to "lock" the keys there is a problem with putting it into the stand we bought to go with it, it presses the #key on it's own. I think its a matter of just getting use to using the "lock"key feature.  All and all she is very happy with this phone.

Reviews.Title: Great for tired eyes - Simple to use!
Reviews.Author: FERLING
Reviews.Content: Simple to use - For any one that wants to call someone or receive calls (can send/receive text also).Easy to see and easy to hear. Big buttons makes it easy to dial with one hand.Signal is great in my location where other phones will not get a signal.Cheap for any one who likes to talk (on a phone) only when they have to.$10.00 (includes tax and all fees) a month for 101 minutes and minutes not used rolls over to next month.Not enough minutes then buy another $10.00 which will give you 150 minutes more (Total = 251 minutes)Nice FM radio built in for when you have time to kill.All I can say is "It Works For Me"

Reviews.Title: Almost there....
Reviews.Author: Ron Smith
Reviews.Content: I purchased this phone for my 80 year old mother. She was previously using a flip phone but was having problems reading it and hearing it. After changing to the Snapfon, those problems were taken care of. The ring tones are loud enough that she can hear them and the display gives large, easily readable characters. She also can hear the conversation easily. She is on my AT&T; Family Plan and all that I had to do was install her AT&T; chip. The only problem she had was that she had to enter the "Menu" to find a phone number. The menu function is foreign to her. Eventually she got it and loves the phone now. I would suggest that the "Menu" button become the "phone book" button. Then access to the menu could be done by someone else (like me) with a combination of buttons (say * and # at the same time) to program the phone. Then the person using it does not have to enter the menu for every day tasks. She was having trouble when she entered the menu function because she would select the wrong item and get lost in the menu. It is more difficult for older people to learn because, when in the menu, it only displays one option and they don't understand that there are other options they can choose. While lost in the menu once, my mother accidentally deleted all of her phone numbers. I think this one change would make this the perfect phone for older people who are not used to cell phones or computers. Make that change and I'll rate this phone 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Great phone for hearing and vision impaired seniors
Reviews.Author: N. Matanic
Reviews.Content: My 81 year old mother has a significant hearing loss and suffers from macular degeneration which results in tremendous vision issues.  I searched far and wide to for a phone that was suitable for her use.  This phone is fantastic and an incredible value.  Although my mothers challenges are great, I would recommend this for any senior just because it is so simple to use.  I was able to very easily add it to my ATT&T; contract.  The sales rep was excited to see the phone, because none of the big carriers has anything available for this large market.  I would suggest that Snapfon start talking to ATT and others and make these phones more readily available.

Reviews.Title: Not a mature product
Reviews.Author: Victor Barrantes
Reviews.Content: I like the phone but still a lot of work to be done by the maker.1. If you're dialing a number (just entering the numbers before you make the actual call) and it happens to receive one incoming call at that particular instant you cannot answer the incoming call, the phones continues to ring but no button take any action. You have to keep the Red key pressed to turn off the phone, is the only way to make it stop ringing.2. The green key sometimes do the function of the menu key and sometimes takes you to the lists of calls, you never know what you will get when pressing that key.3. The lists of calls have no time stamp so you'll never know when a given call was lost, received, done, etc.Those 3 things are critical for me, I don't know if this is just a matter of firmware update or what.

Reviews.Title: Proceed with extreme Caution!!
Reviews.Author: Clark Hartman "MariettaMom"
Reviews.Content: This phone is a double edged situation as far as I'm concerned. My dad is 81 and somewhat computer savvy but on a very low level and he just loves this phone. He can see and hear perfectly and has even learned to text. This phone does not receive any multi media messages like pictures though. On the flip side, in less than one year we are on the THIRD phone purchased from this company. Phone number one conked out and had no display within the first month. Phone number two last longer but within 90 days the screen display went haywire. I could no longer return it through Amazon and had to send about 400 emails back and forth to the vendor who finally had me send it back and I received ZERO response or action from them. I ended buying yet ANOTHER phone for my dad and it has only been a few months now and the phone is going completely dead. He has had to take it to the ATT store and they pulled the battery out and put it back in and it worked again, but I told dad if this phone goes back that is IT! No more, not again. It's a great concept but in my opinion very poorly made and they really don't seem very enthusiastic about customer service either. I would proceed with caution. It's cheap enough but not when you have to buy three a year.

Reviews.Title: Was I ever embarressed, this is a great phone , buy it!
Reviews.Author: Steve C. Michalski "Stevix©"
Reviews.Content: Let me tell you first off that Amazon is combining the Snapfon ezONE reviews with the Snapfon ezTWO and if you have the "Two" like I do .  The Bluetooth DOES WORK!I emailed snapfon and they (Katie) sent me an email back with in hours with a link to all the videos and how to do things on this phone( http://www.snapfon.com/blog/eztwo_videos/) and I watched the video on pairing Bluetooth devices and I could not manage to get my Plantronics Model 320 working .  I called the 800 number she gave me and I spoke with Veronica and I'm sorry to say I was not my best to her and I apolize.  Anyway she connected me with her supervisor Jim and he walked me through it, the problem was getting the headset to be ready to pair not the phone, I felt like an idiot after I bragged how technically competent I was and Jim being the professional that he is took it in stride.So let me tell you  "BUY THIS PHONE"!  it is perfect if you just want to do normal cell phone stuff, yes you can text , and other stuff but its really easy and I just put my ATT Sim card in and I was good to go!The technical support alone makes this phone a worth while purchase alone.  Amazon (Prime) had this phone delievered to my front porch in 15 hours after purchasing it so anyone who thinks that $79.99 cost for prime is high is dead wrong and you also get all those movies & tv shows for free.Thanks again to all.

Reviews.Title: Good for vision impaired
Reviews.Author: Liz
Reviews.Content: My father is legally blind and it's very hard for him to use a regular cell phone.  This one is perfect with the big buttons for the numbers, but also to answer and end calls.  I wish it was a flip phone, cause that would make it even easier to answer and end calls.  The down side is the display screen.  I know you lose some screen for the bigger buttons, but the contrast is bad.  Better the black letters against a white background.  The orange/gold background makes it too hard to see.  But the big buttons are most important, so it works!  Also, he has T-mobile service and it was easy to just install the sim card from his old phone and this phone worked instantly.  It made the best gift!Why aren't all mobile phone companies offering phones like this for seniors or those with disabilities?

Reviews.Title: Not completely Happy with it yet
Reviews.Author: trekker gal
Reviews.Content: Purchased for my elderly mother. Seemed like a good idea from the reviews. Unfortunately she is having trouble adjusting to it.Pros:inexpensiveno contract (if you sign up with the service via ezOneLarge touch keypad numbersClear loud voice that says the numbers as she is dialingthe ring and call audio is VERY loudEasy to set up on AT&T; and if you already  have a family plan with generous minutes the cost is around 9.99. No internet or texting. Texting is an extra $5locking keypad prevents accidental callsFlashlight comes in handyCons:unable to import phone numbers. We had to manually enter themYou cannot enter multiple numbers to one contact so you have to list a contact for each phone number.Buttons stickshortcut dialing difficult to set up. We still have not been able to do it.the buttons stick which might have somethinng to do with the setup issuesVoice mail not easy to set upradio feature not all that good so she doesn't use itShe doesnt like the phonebook. You can only view one number at a time instead of a list of  numbers.The screen with the numbers is small and somewhat difficult to read if you have poor eyesightThe concept is good, which is why I will give it  3 stars. I will update my review in a few weeks to see if she has adjusted to the phone and perhaps will be able to provide a more positive review.UPDATE: had to return this item. The biggest complaint she gave was the phonebook only shows one entry, each entry only had one phone number (where other phones have cell, home etc in one entry). To get to the phonebook is cumbersome for someone with poor eyesight and nimble fingers. The middle menu button which is used to navigate between menu items is impossible to use. No arrows are provided and you have to be careful where you push on it.This phone would be perfect for someone who has no use for the phone book and can manually dial. It is LOUD which is good for those hard of hearing.

Reviews.Title: This is NOT the phone for Seniors!
Reviews.Author: William Marling
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my 90-ish parents. It is NOT the answer. Besides a very cheap "build" (lowest quality plastic, keys stick, battery cover is very balky), its operation is not intuitive. My parents would be coming off a Nokia, but Snapfone software is very primitive. The screen is so small that text messages for refills scroll one word at a time. Programming for the one-text is way beyond Senior capacity.  The ONLY thing this phone has going for it are large keys that sing out when you touch them.  A better bet is to program the one-touch keys on your Seniors' existing phone and tape the numbers to the back.

Reviews.Title: Great simple cell phone
Reviews.Author: Ruth
Reviews.Content: We needed a simple, easy to use cell phone for our 80 year old Mother, While it has taken her some time to get comfortable with it (she accidentally called 911 the first time she tried to use it. She became quite distraught by the 911 operators doing her best to make sure there really wasn't a genuine emergency and then again 2 hours later when a couple of uniformed officers showed up "just to make sure there really wasnt a problem"), she has begun using it and has been able to make and recieve calls, listen to voice-mails and do texts!!!Way to go Mom!!!

Reviews.Title: HORRIBLE for texting, bad interface, bad customer service
Reviews.Author: flotsette
Reviews.Content: I got this for my Mom directly from Snapfon.com. Mom was using her old Razr for texting but it started acting up and she was having trouble pressing the right buttons. So I got her this thinking it would be easy to use, and the buttons would be easy to press.If someone only used this like a phone and didn't use speed dials, it would be fine. The buttons are large and easy to press, and the big screen makes it easy to see.But the phone is absolutely horrible for texting. The menus are terrible, and require far too many button presses to complete any action. The documentation was incorrect -- we had to call the company twice just to get the thing activated and the voice mail set up, because the directions that were given didn't work. The manual makes reference to things (like speed dialing) that are not explained. The charging station is very spotty and doesn't work well.Support is absolutely terrible. They are only open until 4:30 our time and Monday-Friday. And frequently when I called their 800 number, I got a busy signal!  They are a PHONE service and they don't have a hold queue to accommodate their customers? Worst yet, we decided to take them up on the 30-day return guarantee. But it's 30 days from the day you order it online, to the day they receive it back in the mail. This actually gives you more like 20 days to actually try the thing out. Most companies simply require you to get an RMA within the return window, but Snapfon doesn't work that way.Our family has been in crisis with Mom in and out of the hospital, so things got crazy and we lost track of time... I called on day 31, and was out of luck. They wouldn't even let me speak to the manager.We will be changing service and eating the cost of the phone. I would never recommend this phone or the service to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Loud and easy to use.
Reviews.Author: Jeremy W Davis
Reviews.Content: Bought the phone for my father-in-law who has hearing and vision issues.  Works great. I just dropped his AT&T; sim card in and powered it up.  He's able to use it better than his old phone.  The volume is loud enough for him to hear, about half again as loud as a normal phone.  The buttons are large and tactile enough for him to dial with, and the display is large and uncluttered.  SeniorTech got it to me quick.

Reviews.Title: Finally! A real solution. Just one flaw...
Reviews.Author: Specklebang
Reviews.Content: I'm low vision (daylight driving only) and I'll be 70 in about a minute.I've struggled with a number of cell phones over the years squinting my way through menus, sub-menus and sub-sub menus. While my hearing is fair, I've never been able to use a cell phone as a confortable, viable alternative to a land-line.Well, finally, here it is. Simple, functional, uncomplicated and good voice quality. The perfect, light-weight cell phone.It has only one flaw - a somewhat serious one. It comes with 10 ringtones and they are all obnoxious. Sure, you'll hear them but you sure won't enjoy them. They really need to supply one softer, pleasant chime as an option.I've had it for 4 days and I'm planning on changing out all my senior friends phones with these. But first, I want that ringtone issue fixed by adding one decent ringtone.Otherwise, wow, it's great. Delivered overnight!(one more small complaint. The proprietary car charger is terribly overpriced at $13)

Reviews.Title: Not perfect, but the best I could find
Reviews.Author: C. Seaton "death by research"
Reviews.Content: My mom had a stroke and she isn't able to figure out how to call me or use the phone book function on a cellphone anymore.  To make it even worse, she is almost deaf.  She also gets confused easily and tries to manually input my cell phone number, but often mis-dials and calls other people in my town, but can't hear them speaking when they answer and so she calls them over and over and over.She lives in my home but I often can't hear her when she hollers for me.  So I purchased this Snapfon ezONE-C.  The first one was defective, and I sent it back.  Also, don't bother purchasing the cradle accessory, you don't need it to charge the phone.  The one I got was flimsy and didn't even work to charge the phone at all and I sent it back.  I did get the lanyard and attach it so Mom had something extra to hang on to.Here is how the Snapfon has solved a few of our problems:  On the back side of the phone is a bright red candy-like SOS button.  Every day I ask my mother, how do you call me?  And I watch to see that she can point to the red button and count to five.  The SOS button can be programmed to text several numbers with an emergency message of your choosing, and I think it can also phone a list of emergency numbers from your contact list.  Every time she texts me it uses 10 cents of our ATT pay as you go time.  I have also programmed keypad #9 for 911 and another keypad # to quickdial me.When I am home, I use the sliding lock mechanism on the side of the phone to prevent her from trying to dial out on her own because she can't do it, but still wants to try.  This saves airtime and my neighbors from going nuts with the whole dial and ditch thing.  Even if the keypad is locked, the emergency button on the back still functions and she can answer when I call her back.  There is a nice super loud ring tone that she can actually hear.The things I don't like about the phone:  The fm radio switch on the side.  She accidentally turns it on, and it hisses loudly but she can't hear it.  The flashlight:  same thing.  I'd just rather have a basic phone with nothing she can accidentally turn on.  The phone feels a bit flimsy but so far it does the job.  The first one I bought was sent back because the lock button only worked intermittently and I had to remove the battery to unlock the phone.I'm using this in conjunction with a nursery monitor to try and keep better tabs on my Mom who has fallen a few times, and then not been able to figure out the cell phone she carried to call me for help.  She does seem to remember the red SOS button.

Reviews.Title: Sorry to say I am disappointed
Reviews.Author: Donna
Reviews.Content: I ordered this phone for my 89 year old Dad who lives in an assisted living facility.  He is having difficulty using the phone and there were many times when he unknowingly either shut it down or touched buttons that caused some settings to change.  For instance, just yesterday a family member was helping him use the phone and found it to be switched to silent mode.  This stuff has been happening continually since he got the phone a few weeks ago.The speaker phone is difficult for him to operate, also.  You have to hold the 0 button down when you are on a call.  My Dad can't hear it very well when he first answers it and he takes it away from his ear to look for the zero to get the speaker phone to function. It takes him a little while to get it all settled and sometimes loses the caller.Sometimes when he ends the call, if he presses the red button down too long it shuts the phone down and he doesn't realize it.I never wrote a review before but I think this is very important for others to know.  A flip type phone seems like it would be better because there would be less chance of hitting the keys when the phone is in his pocket.  There's no way he could remember to lock and unlock the phone each time.  I do not recommend this phone.

Reviews.Title: 85 year old purchase a Snapfon ezONE
Reviews.Author: John J. Baker
Reviews.Content: I have visual and hearing problems, but with this phone I can see the buttons and have the volume turned up to hear my calls, this phone was simply to set up.With the emergency  button this is a must for most active seniors

Reviews.Title: Works Great
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Sobel "jasobel"
Reviews.Content: Easy to use- If you want just a phone, this is the right product. Easy to setup- Insert SIM (AT&T; Pay As You Go), and start making calls. Great Product.

Reviews.Title: Easy To Learn and Use
Reviews.Author: Pamela
Reviews.Content: The Snapfon was purchased for an elderly family member who had difficulty using other mobile phones. So far, this phone has been easy to learn and to use all of the features by this relative. The only issue I have is the phone has a radio feature that will never be used by this relative. Snapfon should make it an option.

Reviews.Title: Great Value
Reviews.Author: AndresGzzM
Reviews.Content: Bought this phone for my grandmother and she loves it.  The fact that she has the "SOS" button (that works great by the way) makes her feel safe at all times.

Reviews.Title: disapointed
Reviews.Author: amazonuser
Reviews.Content: I bought this cell phone for my father who is 86 years old and has hearing problem.  I spent a lot time searching for a good phone for him online and was hoping this phone will work with 1) AT&T; service, 2) having load ring tone and 3) have high receiving volume.  But the phone is big disappointment.  First, although the phone is compatible with AT&T; service, the reception is horrible: it is not clear and it does not has signal a lot of time from his apartment where other cell phones always have signals.  Secondly, the receiving volume is so low, that he couldn't hear anything with or without hearing aid.  The only thing working is the ring tone is load enough.  I wanted to return the phone, but my father has already had the phone for more than 30 days and returning would not get much money back.  My advice is don't buy this phone for any seniors who has hearing problem and if you want to buy a phone for seniors go to local phone services (AT&T;, Verizon or any other services) to choose and test the phone before buy it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for grandma or grandpa!
Reviews.Author: CG
Reviews.Content: I bought two of this cellphones and I gave them to my grandmothers (around 83 years old). They both loved it, it's easy to use and all sounds are very loud (they always said that they didn`t hear the phone, now they say that they are not deff haha) and the screen and the numbers are so big they can actually see what they need. It has only the basic things, which is exactly what my grandmothers needed. The SOS button is very good if something happens, and the other buttons around the cellphone are so easy to use.The only issue I saw (I don`t know if I am wrong or if the cellphones I received have something wrong but the issue I say), is that the +/- button (at the side of the cellphone) is to change the volume of the keyboard and if you want to change the volume of the ringtone you need to wait until someone calls you and then you can change the volume. Off course there are other "easy" ways to change the ringtone volume, but for an 83 year old person "only 3 steps" are a lot, and I simply could not teach them how to turn off the volume. I had to tell them to turn off the cellphone when they where in church but I was not so happy with this and I really think that the manufacturer should change this. If they are in church, it would be great that they move the +/- button up or down to change the volume, because this way is so easy.

Reviews.Title: Cheap phone, but works
Reviews.Author: kmichel
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Snapfone for my 93 year old father. It works is about all I can say.Pros:The voice quality is good, and it has quite a loud volume when turned up which is nice for the elderly. The buttons are large and easy to see, and it speaks the numbers as they are pressed. The SOS button on the back is a nice feature. The phone does not come with any sort of service, so it has to be added to a cellular plan - but it is unlocked and will work with any GSM carrier without a contract ( in the USA).Cons:Features like voicemail, texting, and address book are accessed through the arrow buttons. I have found this to be too confusing for a 93 year old. It was easier to teach him to simply press the numbers for the number he wants and "press the green button." (or red to hang up). Getting him to understand how to use the voicemail has also been a challenge, so I usually end up having to check it for him.  Also, the phone is made quite cheaply.Overall, what you get for the price is good.

Reviews.Title: Ok phone but problems for some people
Reviews.Author: Mike Rachuk
Reviews.Content: I purchase this phone for my wife because she has a vision impairment problem. The 2 good things about this phone is that it is very load and the keys and text are large.  For the most part this is an OK phone with no frills.On the other side, we kept missing calls because the phone would not ring. I had set the ringer at the lowest level because it is very load and my wife was in the hospital when we received the phone. Every time I checked the ringer setting it was turned off. We finally realized that if you hit the minus volume key when you are not on a call the phone lowers the ringer volume. So if the ringer is set to the lowest level before it goes to off, then the first accidental hit of the minus volume shuts the ringer off. The placement of the up/down volume keys makes it very easy to accidentally change the ringer volume. I have to admit it is mentioned in the owner's manual that hitting the up/down volume key changes the ringer volume when not on a call. It does not warn you that it can shut the ringer off. For a senior with vision impairment, this is a problem in my opinion. I think the only way you should be able to shut the ringer off is in the setup menu.The placement of the up/down switch of the side of the phone also created problems when listening to calls. If your hand touches the switch while you are listening to a call it will change the volume to include shutting the speaker off. This happened several times during our use of the phone. After surgery her hands were not as steady as before and the phone would shut the speaker off. After tying to call my wife and her answering the phone but not being able to hear me we decided we didn't want to deal with this phone anymore. A phone is meant for communications and that can't happen when the ringer or speaker is shut off.Neither of us was satisfied with the voice quality of the calls either.After trying to contact my wife on Thursday and not being able to get thru, we decided it was time to get rid of the phone. We purchase the phone directly from Snapfon. I called customer support at Snapfon and they were very nice. They looked up my order and said we had the phone for over 30 days and we could not return it for a refund. I explain my wife had surgery and was in the hospital for 5 weeks, but that didn't make any difference. We were 10 days past the limit and rules are rules. I talked to another person at Snapfon and got the same answer.Lessons learned: 1-read every word in the instruction manual and then read it again, 2-The first time your wife says she does not like the phone, send it back before the 30 limit. We will give this phone to somebody that can use it. We don't like the phone and will get a different phone.Mike Rachuk

Reviews.Title: Satisfaction to be Determined
Reviews.Author: lvance "LVance"
Reviews.Content: I ordered a Snapfon for my mom over a year ago. One year and one month later that phone died and could not be revived--how convenient that it expired just barely past the one-year warranty.  :-/  I wanted her to try another brand, but she, being the optimist, said she would try the Snapfon one more time. At $80 per phone, it is too expensive for her to be replacing these phones on an annual basis. She is retired, on a fixed income, and like so many of the elderly, has ongoing medical expenses. So we shall see how long this second phone endures....

Reviews.Title: Don't buy this phone
Reviews.Author: S. Pirtle "margrad"
Reviews.Content: I wasn't there when my mother got her phone, but she seemed to have a very hard time learning to use it.  However I have talked to her, with her using the phone many times and the sound quality is very poor.  Also she still seems to be having trouble working with it.  That of course could just be her.UPDATE: I went to visit my mother.  I was shocked at the poor quality of this device.  it is cheaply made: very light, and very small.  that is why the keys look so big. My sister gave mother and old phone left over from a phone contract some years back.  She loves the old phone.  I tossed the Snapfon in the trash!

Reviews.Title: for father in law (79, low vision)
Reviews.Author: evelyn m. trivoli
Reviews.Content: We added my father in law (79 - with very low vision) onto our ATT plan to save him $$. He had to get a new phone (he has used a cell for a long time) in order to be with ATT. I found this and ordered it online. It seems to be the best one for simplicity and features for low-vision. Even the ATT staff said they don't have anything as 'clear' and simple as this.He is getting used to it. The only drawback we can see so far is the sound quality is BAD. The first time he called us--I had no idea who was calling - his voice had changed! Sounds like he's talking through a filter.The phone is light and about the size of a deck of cards. Another reviewer said the keys feel like 'cheap calculator keys' and that's correct. As long as it holds up, it will be fine (keep the packaging and warranty info). Dad doesn't use his cell all that much anyway.

Reviews.Title: WOW...GREAT CELL PHONE!
Reviews.Author: Judy
Reviews.Content: Grandpa and I just "LOVE" our 2 New Snapfons!!  Wow...just great cellphones!!  Great...Reception...CALLS NEVER DROPPED!!  PLUS..only a $10 a month contract with Talk USA--for 100 min's. each month...and...min's not used...is "rolled over" to add to next month!! That's GREAT!!  Also...biggest feature....Grandpa can "hear" his cell phone ring in his pant pocket, too!!  Plus..."EASY" to use....BIG BUTTONS AND....NO..."complicated features"...just call and talk!!  That's all we needed.  We had AT&T; cell phones for 8 years...($74/mo for our 2 cell phones) and they were "awful"! We got terrible reception...dropped calls...and...we could not hearour cell phones when it rang in my purse or Grandpa's pant pockets. Also..we never used the camera...or...give a darn about "texting"...and never used all the other "complicated features".  All we needed was to call and talk on a cell phone!!  We are sooo happy with our New SNAPFON CELL PHONES!! Just wished they had Snapfons 8 years ago...I would have never gotten those awful-expensive cell phones from AT&T.;  We "highly recommend"  anyone to buy a SNAPFON!! I tell you...theselittle cell phones are GREAT!!!

Reviews.Title: good for old folks
Reviews.Author: GiniusTFLord
Reviews.Content: nice phone good size numbers, it can talk to you in diferent languages, dont like the menue if you wanna call a contact you have to go thrugh the menue to get to it. in every other phone you just press down on the center buton to get to who you want, thats the simple way to do it. also the screen window should be bigger. and a radio? WTH for? if you want a radio this small pice of junk isent it. flash light is a good idea, like that the lock button is a bit hard and for older folks can be confusing. if theyd just corect these few isues this would be an awsome phone for older folks. but as it its its problably still one of the best options out there at the moment so i would recomend it. and my dads using it with t-Moble and a life line account.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Pat Tierney
Reviews.Content: I purchased this phone for my husband who is disabled.  Everything about his phone is wonderful, especially the emergency alert button on the back.  I took it to AT&T; and had it set up in no time.  The lady there said she would look into getting one for her grandfather who is blind, because she loved the fact that the phone spoke the numbers you dialled. I would highly recommend this phone.

Reviews.Title: Great Snapfon
Reviews.Author: Mickey
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my 84 year old Mother. She needed something simple and easy to read.  She also is able to hear conversations clearly and the ring is loud enough for her to hear.  She feels much better now that she has a way to talk to family any time she needs to.  We checked several cell phone models before finding this one, she is able to see the numbers and to dial easily because of the big buttons.  It does not have a lot of fancy features but it had the necessary ones for her. It was a little smaller than I wanted but she hasn't had trouble keeping up with it.  She is happy and so are we.  I would recommend it to anyone who needs a simple way to keep in touch with family & friends.

Reviews.Title: Not so Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: Review revised: Downgraded.The phone has large buttons and a large font display.  If you could get used to the more complicated "navigation" it might be easier to make calls on.The phone itself is not much, if any, larger than most mobile phones, so since the keys are larger (and they are much larger) there are not as many keys.  So the usual "soft keys" are missing and the "call" and "end" key must serve multiple functions. This makes navigation more complex than a standard mobile phone.  Green key (call) is also used much like an <enter> key and one must scroll through options using the center (Menu) key and the call key. The end key is also the "no" key and is used to back up through the processes.Also the Snapfon does not provide some common options like call forwarding.  We put the Sim card in another phone to program call forwarding and some other options that are not in the Snapfon's "settings" menu.  It does not indicate the time/date on missed calls either.  Snapfon could add more features to their settings menu but it would be more complicated to use.We are returning the phone because switching from a standard phone to this one is confusing.  A "gadget geek" might like it.We would not buy it again.

Reviews.Title: Just what Mom needed
Reviews.Author: K. T. Viscuso
Reviews.Content: From the moment I handed Mom this phone I knew it would be a hit.  All I had to do beforehand was pop in the AT&T; SIM from her old phone and throw the phone on the charger.  She's had it for a few weeks so far and hasn't had an issue.  It does exactly what she and I need it to do.  The call clarity surpasses that of the Samsung slider that it replaced.  Make sure to test the S.O.S. function before handing it over, as it isn't as fast as dialing 911.  I think that the delay is built in, to give the user the chance to cancel.  Makes sense to me...The phone arrived in perfect shape, packed well and on time.  Usual Amazon fare there.

Reviews.Title: Love My Snapton!
Reviews.Author: Budd Blume
Reviews.Content: I'm 88 and am retired in Mexico. I had mu doubts about connectivity, but went ahead an ordered one anyway. Easy as pie, once ig I had it ""smuggled" in by a US house guest.  All it took to hook into TelCel, our cell phone provider, was insertion of  the SIM from my little (too little to see!)  Nokia phone, a cell to TelCel Central by my neighborhood cel phone store, and I was in business.I like everything about my Snapton. Not too big, excellent visibility, good hear-ability battery life (1 week), and ease of operation.Five Stars.  Budd Blume

Reviews.Title: Bought it for my 91 year-old dad
Reviews.Author: carinskarin
Reviews.Content: Easy to read numbers and great volume. The only drawback is that we can't use the SOS button because Snapfon is the required service provider for that. He hasn't needed the SOS button yet but may need it soon. I have T-Mobile and we have a family plan. I may need to pay a few dollars more for Snapfon.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing
Reviews.Author: Matthew Kennedy
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my 85 year old dad.It was easy to set-up and use.Problem is it is there seems to be something wrong  with the phone's microphone. On a call he can hear me, but it's very hard to understand him. I've tried troubleshooting - how he holds the phone, etc, but it's hard to help from 2000 miles away.There are a couple reviews that mention the same problem.Considering that the only expectation for this phone was that it makes calls, this is a fail.

Reviews.Title: Beware! Phone lacks basic features.
Reviews.Author: S. Rogers
Reviews.Content: This phone should be marketed strictly for really elderly people, not "seniors" in general. It was a Christmas present for my husband, who is 70 and needs something easy to use. But this phone has two flaws that we consider major and are why we sent it back: 1) You cannot turn off the music that plays every time you turn it on or off! If your volume is set anywhere near "hear-able," everyone around you will hear when you turn it on or off. Do Snapfon users never go to the movies or travel on a plane? You could probably turn the volume all the way down before turning it off, but then you'd have to remember to turn it up again when turning it back on. Either involves repeated pressing of a toggle on the side. NOT!2) You cannot set this phone to Vibrate Only, just Vibrate & Ring (together) if you want it to vibrate. So, if you are expecting a call but don't want to disturb those around you, again you have to turn the volume all the way down. (And then later, after your meeting or movie, remember to turn the volume back up again). The nice young woman at Snapfon said these two features were not there for "simplicity" reasons, but my husband and I consider them basic, so it's going back. Too bad, we had wanted the Unlocked feature for a trip overseas in April.[LATER] Realized we can't return it because the box has been opened, we've used the phone trying to figure it out, and my husband already wrote the phone number (from the AT&T; sim card we bought separately) on the instruction booklet. So, we're stuck with it, but at least will have something to use in Europe in a few months, even if it is annoying.

Reviews.Title: The text on menus is tiny
Reviews.Author: Needed a faucet
Reviews.Content: This phone is horrible for the disabled.Text too small, no audible module announcements, and buttons that are all crammed onto a single piece of rubberized plastic.

Reviews.Title: This is for Consumer Cellular Customers
Reviews.Author: Bradford K. Talamon
Reviews.Content: The Snapfon EZ TWO does work with Consumer Cellular's SIM card and it works great.  However, PLEASE NOTE that it does NOT work with Consumer Cellular's older SIM cards!My experience went like this: I had an old Nokia cell phone with one of Consumer Cellular's SIM cards in it (2 or 3 years old) and when I put that SIM card in the Snapfon EZ TWO, it didn't work.  (Note - Snapfon has excellent instructional video clips at their website that demonstrate every espect of how to use the features of the Snapfon EZ TWO...and they have one for how to install the SIM card)I called the Consumer Cellular Customer Service number (888-345-5508) and talked to the Tech Support people and I was told that the older Consumer Cellular SIM cards don't work with many of the newer cell phones and they have to send you a new SIM card.  I asked them to do so (programmed with my current cell phone number), which they do for free.  It takes about 2 or 3 days to get to you because they mail it to you from Portland, Oregon.  When you receive the new SIM card, put it into the Snapfon EZ TWO and then you have to call Consumer Cellular to have it activated.After the new SIM card is activated, your new Snapfon EZ TWO will be working with Consumer Cellular's service.  And that is how we do that!P.S. - You may not have to go through this when you are transferring a SIM card from a phone with one of Consumer Cellular's newer SIM cards...at least that's what they told me.  If, however, your cell phone provider is Consumer Cellular and your original SIM card doesn't work with your Snapfon EZ TWO, this is what you have to do to make it work.  I hope that this explanation helps.  I love the features.  They are the features that I want in a cell phone and will use.UPDATE: 12/26/2013: IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT VOICEMAIL ACTIVATION: Because I was using a Consumer Cellular SIM card, I had to have initial assistance from Consumer Cellular's Customer Service Department to set up my voicemail.  The directions for setting up my voicemail didn't work until after Consumer Cellular programmed my SIM card.  After they program your SIM card (using their computer to do this over the phone), you just follow the Snapfon EZ TWO Instructions to set up your voicemail.  They will walk you through the process to get the IMEI number (serial number) from your SIM card so they can program it.  You have to call their Customer Service number (888-345-5508) to do this.  This call does NOT count against your monthly total of minutes.  It's a very easy process and their customer service is very good.  Voicemail was the only Snapfon EZ TWO feature that I needed Consumer Cellular's assistance to set up.Neither Snapfone's nor Consumer Cellular's instructions for setting up voicemail tell you this.

Reviews.Title: My 89 year old mother uses this phone daily and has no problems using it
Reviews.Author: RG0647
Reviews.Content: This phone was for my 89 year old mother who does not like digital technology.  She likes the phone because of the big numbers and simple display.  She wanted a basic telephone, not the sophistication of an IPhone.  I programmed her favorite numbers into speed dial so it is hit one number and place the call.  She was comfortable with the phone after a couple of days use.  From my perspective, the reason for not being five stars, is the provided users manual is not adequate in its description of what the phone can do.  If you use the website version and especially the frequently asked questions then you can find out what ever you need in setting up the phone.  I added her to my Tmobile account for $10.00 instead of getting her a landline for $50.00.  Tmobile programmed the SIM card and the phone was working within an hour after the SIM card was installed.  I would buy this phone again for an elderly person.

Reviews.Title: NICE SENIOR PHONE
Reviews.Author: CHERYL
Reviews.Content: EVERY SENIOR SHOULD BUY THIS PHONE.I PURCHASED THIS PHONE OVER 3 YRS AGO AND MY 85 YR OLD MOTHER HAD NO PR 0BLEMS USING THIS PHONE ...IT HAS A RADIO AND THE NUMBERS ARE VISIBLE AN IT IS LOUD IF YOU HAVE A HEARING PROB, BUT YOU CAN ADJUST THE VOLUME....SO MANY  NEAT FEATURES....

Reviews.Title: Great Phone but service coverage lacking
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: The phone has great features but you cannot use with standard well served service providers like Verizon or ATT.  Snapfone offer service but their coverage is lousy and calls are dropped which is not what a senior is looking for.  Seniors want reliable service along with an easy phone.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Product
Reviews.Author: Gustavo A. Darino "always learning"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this phone for my 81 Year old Dad. The screen is easy to see and the numbers are nice and Big. The language can be changed to Spanish. The inclusion of a Camera and LED Flashlight is a mixed blessing. I don't see my Dad using them and he gets confused as to what button does what. A more technically inclined Senior may find this two additions helpful. The volume is good and ringtones loud. I wish I could remove the buttons for the Camera and LED light to avoid this confusion. An option to install custom ringtones would be nice but overall I have no regrets.

Reviews.Title: Great phone.
Reviews.Author: Michael Wendlinger
Reviews.Content: We like the phone. The only improvement i would wish for is that a picture can be saved for every contact so the picture of the caller is displayed on the screen during incoming call. I think this could help people who are not so literate to identify the caller. Shouldn't be a big problem to program since the camera is already available.

Reviews.Title: Nice Phone for Elderly People!
Reviews.Author: Urban Knight
Reviews.Content: Phone was just as stated. I have had it a while now, and it works very well. I got it for my elderly mom. She can see what she is dialing, and it is simple enough for her to know what she is doing(most of the time). I got it for her to use T-Mobile pre-paid Gold plan. For those of you who don't know, you can buy 1000 minutes for $100,that will last a year, then add any size dollar amount card and it will roll over for another year! For people who don't use their phone much, this is a great plan!Robert

Reviews.Title: I think it's a winner
Reviews.Author: Jamie
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my 75 yr old father who is at times very hard to satisfy and so far, it seems to please.  Works well with his network, large display, large keys, loud sounds.  The only thing I have heard him say he didn't like was that the time automatically changes depending on time zone he's in and he would rather it stay on his home location.  It has a side slick keypad lock which I personally think is wonderful.  I would recommend for anyone who wants a phone with not a lot of bells and whistles or someone who wants an easy to use phone.  Oh, and it has a camera too!!

Reviews.Title: Great Senior Phone for T-mobile
Reviews.Author: AZ Mum
Reviews.Content: My mum loves this phones.  She likes the large screen and big numbers.  I installed the T-Mobile SMS card and it worked.  No problems.P.S. The SOS button can not be used unless you have snapfon service.

Reviews.Title: Simple & Easy to Use!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Slathessia"
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my mother. She had difficulty dialing and reading the display on her T-Mobile phone. We bought a lariat to go with the phone so it is easy for her to carry it when we go out to the store or park, and even around the house. We love the lock keypad feature on the side of the phone (helps when the two year old happens to grab hold of it). The emergency button on the back is also and excellent feature. It helps to know that if she falls in her bedroom we can hear the alarm, or if she is alone she can easily press the button to reach 911. The phone has been such a success we're considering buying one for my mother-in-law.

Reviews.Title: Really good phone
Reviews.Author: RichieOT
Reviews.Content: Exactly as described. Very easy to operate and learn to use. do not have to reach for glasses any more to operate the phone.

Reviews.Title: excellent gift
Reviews.Author: Kimberley Chandler
Reviews.Content: i bought this for my 90 year old mother and she loves it.  It's easy for her to read and use.  Perfect Senior phone!

Reviews.Title: phone
Reviews.Author: donald moraski
Reviews.Content: Bought the phone for y elderly parent they like the ease of using the phone  it was a  great buy for them

Reviews.Title: Great Phone for the Elderly
Reviews.Author: J. Fife "CaptJoe"
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my mom. She has dementia and is blind in one eye. She resides in a full care nursing facility and wanted a phone she could easily use. This is the only phone I have found that she can successfully use. Big numbers when pressed speak the number so dialing mistakes are down to almost zero. Numbers can be stored and then used for speed dialing so all she has to do is press a single number and listen and success.Guess this phone could be enjoyed by anyone but it excels for people that need a tad bit of help. It is a no nonsense simple phone. All I did to activate it was to go to AT&T; and have them put a SIM card in it.Update: The snapon2 that I received for my mom had 10 speed dial slots. For whatever reason I was notified that it only had 8. Not true in my case.

Reviews.Title: Love it!!
Reviews.Author: Sonia I. Mcalister "Sonia I. McAlister"
Reviews.Content: This is a great phone, my mother is blind in one eye and the numbers are really big!! This phone was well worth the money!!  Great great phone.  Easy to program, she loves it!!

Reviews.Title: For 81 year old mother
Reviews.Author: Rawbin "bubblescubed"
Reviews.Content: I got this for mom, 81 years old.  She couldn't figure out how to use flip phones.  She didn't need a camera, internet, texting, or any other fancy stuff.  The jitterbug costs too much for monthly use and I wanted her to be comfortable talking for as long as she wanted.  Now she's happy, we're happy, and I could add her to my AT&T; account.

Reviews.Title: Works well for visual impairment!
Reviews.Author: J.P. "J.P."
Reviews.Content: I bought this phone for my father-in-law who needed a simple phone that would be easy to operate with tactile sensation as his visual ability is severely impaired. This phone works well for him and is not locked to a carrier which allows him to use it in his home country of Brazil and also use it in the U.S. when he is here visiting. The programmable presets for emergency numbers accessible from a large button on the back added extra peace of mind that is so valuable it is worth the purchase price for this feature alone. The build quality is rugged and after several months of use he is still very happy with this phone.

Reviews.Title: It's Okay. But Not for Everyone...Elderly Included!
Reviews.Author: Jamesisit "Jamesisit"
Reviews.Content: I bought this Phone Specificly for my Aged Father who just went into a Nursing Home.  The Phones Size is Smaller than Expected, but the Buttons are Large.  The Major Design with this Phone is it's Designed to be a Seniors Phone, but Far Too Many Gadgets were included. The Sliding Buttons on the Side are just plain Stupid! FM radio, LED Flashlight, Phone Button Lock, and Volume all on the Sides where a Seniors Larger Unsteady Hands Slide them by accident Far to Often!
